FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM
Nebraska State Historical Society
Crawford, Nebraska

address.addrLine: Profesor of Creative Writing and Poeet in Residence

div1.p: I have recently had a note from Louise Mortensen of Des Moines, Iowa. She tells me you were unaware of the establishment of the Fort Robinson Museum of the Nebraska State Historical Society and suggested I send you some of our literature.
I hope these brochures will be of interest to you and that you will have opportunity to visit the museum at a future date.

DESK PIONEER GALLERY INDIAN GALLERY STEPS TO BASEMENT COLLECTOR'S LANE ORIENTATION SECTION STEPS TO 2nd FLOOR PERIOD ROOMS
NEBRASKA STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY 1500 R Street Lincoln 8 Nebraska
Visit the Nebraska State Historical Society Museum
... where life in the Great Plains is recreated...
33
Step into the past and retrace the story of man's occupation of the Plains area!
Photograph of Museum Display About Stone Working
STONE WORKING WORKING IS NOT A LOST ART --
Colorful exhibits displayed in a new, ultramodern, air conditioned building interpret the dramatic story of the Indian and the white pioneer.
The first inhabitants of this area were prehistoric Indian hunters, of approximately ten thousand years ago, who scattered their chipped stone projectile points across the Plains, evidence today of their skill as stone workers.
Agriculture came to the Plains with prehistoric Indian hunters, whose earthlodge villages, cornfields, and prowess as buffalo hunters established a pattern for the way of life followed by their historic successors in eatern and central Nebraska—the Pawnee, Omaha, Ponca, and Oto.
Latecomers to the Plains were the tribes of western Nebraska—the Cheyenne, Arapaho, and the Dakota Sioux—proud, warlike, horse-riding, buffalo-hunting nomads whose home was the tipi.
Photograph of Museum Display Showing Native American Houses
NOMADIC WARRIORS CHEYENNE ARAPAHOE DAKOTA-SIOUX
Drawing of a Woman Working in a Cornfield
Nebraska State Historical Society Building
NEBRASKA STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY
THE NEBRASKA STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY
• Location
15th and R Streets, just east of the University of Nebraska Student Union. • Museum
Exhibits in our galleries are arranged in chronological sequence. Visitors should remember to turn to the left as they enter each gallery to get the complete story as it unfolds.
Entrance area exhibits summarize the story of man in Nebraska from the earliest Indian hunters of ten thousand years ago to present-day irrigation practices in Nebraska. They are intended to give the visitor an orientation to the rest of the Museum.
The Indian Gallery, located in the west wing of the first floor, presents the colorful story of the Plains Indians from prehistoric times to the present.
The Pioneer Gallery, located in the east wing of the first floor, interprets the story of the white pioneer from the fur traders to the present time.
A special exhibits gallery, located in the west end of the second floor, features four period rooms and other special exhibits.
Collector's Lane, located in the basement, is a series of special exhibits of items commonly collected by hobbyists. • Library
The Society maintains an excellent reference library composed of books, manuscripts, archives, newspapers, genealogical materials, and photographs related to the history of Nebraska and the West. Located on the second floor, the library is open to the public. • Hours 8:00 A.M. - 5:30 P.M., Monday through Saturday 2:00 P.M. - 5:00 P.M., Sunday
The building will be closed on New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. • Admission
Admission is free at all times. • Parking Areas
Space is provided in front of the building for buses. There is also limited parking space behind the building. The entrance to this parking area is on S Street.
Photograph of a Fireplace
Drawing of a Covered Wagon
Fur traders led the way West, followed by soldiers, missionaries, Mormons, prospectors and settlers, as young Americans took to the overland trails in search of adventure and a better way of life.
A roadblock to western expansion appeared in the form of well-organized Indian resistence to the encroachment of the white man on the time-honored hunting lands of the red man.
But the Indians soon became islands in the midst of permanent white settlements as homesteaders staked claims to land and built sod houses of "Nebraska marble."
Life on the frontier was often difficult and primitive, but touches of eastern culture appeared in the older Missouri River towns, as in this early Victorian parlor from the John L. Carson home in Brownville, Nebraska.
hokahe! INDIAN WARS SWEEP THE PLAINS 1954-76
Early Victorian Parlor from the John L. Carson home in Brownville, Nebraska
Photograph of 19th Century Women's Clothing
JOHN G. NEIHARDT CENTER
Free land and greater opportunities lured immigrant settlers from European countries. Nebraska became a melting pot of many nationalities, races and creeds.
Nebraska's beef cattle industry came up the trail from Texas after completion of the Union Pacific Railroad when Texas cattlemen sought transportation and a market for their herds of longhorns.
Nebraska State Capitol Building
Photography of a Saddle on a Fence
Nebrskans of today step into the future with confidence born of a long tradition of succesfful adaptation to the Plains country!
ABOUT THE FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM: The Fort Robinson Museum is a branch of the Nebraska State Historical Society. It was first opened to the public on June 3, 1956. The exhibits in the museum summarize the story of man in western Nebraska from Nebraska from prehistoric times to the present. The museum is open all year.
Fort Robinson Museum hours:
8:00 to 5:00, Monday through Saturday 1:00 to 5:00, Sunday
There is no admission charge at any time.
ABOUT THE NEBRASKA STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY
The State Historical Society and Library Association was founded in 1867, the year Nebraska was admitted to the Union. It was reorganized as the Nebraska State Historical Society in 1878. It was constituted a state organization by act of the Nebraska Legislature in 1883 and designated custodian of all public records, documents and other materials of historical value by legislative act of 1905. In 1953 the Society moved into its present air-conditioned building at 1500 R Street, Lincoln, Nebraska. This modern building houses an outstanding historical museum and an excellent library and archives.
Memberships in the Nebraska State Historical Society is open to all. Members participate in the government of the Society and receive NEBRASKA HISTORY, published quarterly and the monthly HISTORICAL NEWSLETTER. Applications for memberships may be directed to Dr. W. D. Aeschbacher, Director, Nebraska State Historical Society, 1500 R Street, Lincoln, Nebraska.
Annual Membership.......$2.00
Life Membership........$50.00
MEMBERSHIPS MAY ALSO BE SECURED THROUGH THE OFFICE OF THE FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM
THE FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM
NEBRASKA STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY
34
PREHISTORY. . . . .
Drawing of An Arrowhead
The record of man goes back more than 10,000 years in Nebraska! The Fort Robinson Museum story begins with the prehistoric Indian period ......and.....
continues with................... INDIAN TRIBES OF THE HISTORIC PERIOD
During the nineteenth century the Fort Robinson area as in the heartland of Sioux Indian territory. The Oglala and Brule groups of the Teton Dakota (Sioux) camped in the butte-rimmed valley of the White River. Many of the exhibits in the museum illustrate the way of life of these horse-riding, bison-hunting tipi dwellers.
RED CLOUD AGENCY 1873-1877 SUTLER'S STORE
The site of Old Red Cloud Indian Agency is about two mules from the museum. It was here that the government issued supplies to the Oglala. The site is marked by a monument, but none of the original buildings remain. Fort Robinson was established in March, 1874 for the purpose of enforcing peace at Red Cloud Agency.
Captain Arthur MacArthur signed the first post return at Camp Robinson. The post was named in honor of Lt. Levi Robinson, killed by the Sioux near Fort Laramie in February, 1874. In 1878 the name was changed to Fort Robinson. The first barracks were made of logs, and the original officers' quarters were adobe. The adobe buildings are still standing.
THE FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM IS LOCATED ON HIGHWAY U.S. 20, FOUR MILES WEST OF CRAWFORD, NEBRASKA
Partial Map o Nebraska
TO THE BLACK HILLS 2 CHADRON FUR TRADE MUSEUM TO YELLOWSTONEPART FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM CRAWFORD 2 AGATE MUSEUM 29 87 2 19 SCOTTSBLUFF SCOTTS BLUFF MONUMENT 19
Photo of Red Cloud Agency Site
Red Cloud Agency Site
LOCATED IN THE SCENIC PINE RIDGE COUNTRY
Fort Robinson was an active post during the Indian campaigns of 1876-1877 and was itself the scene of violence and battle.
Photo of Crazy Horse's Shirt
Crazy Horse's Shirt......on display in the museum
Crazy Horse, renowned Sioux warrior, died in a struggle at the doorway of the Fort Robinson guardhouse September 5, 1877.
Fort Robinson was also the site of the last desperate bid for freedom made by the Northern Cheyenne under Dull Knife's leadership. Breaking out of a log prison at Fort Robinson, the Cheyenne fought a bitter, savage battle with the Army on the parade ground and in the surrounding battles in January 1879. It ended with death or recapture for all but a few of the Cheyenne.
Many well known people played a part in the history of Fort Robinson. A few of these are:
Photograph of Bust of General George Crook
General George Crook
Photograph of Bust of Captain Walter Reed, Post Surgeon
Capt. Walter Reed, post surgeon
Photograph of Bust of California Joe, Scout
California Joe, Scout
Photograph of Bust of Little Bat, Scout
Little Bat, Scout
Photograph of Bust of Major Frank North, Pawnee Scouts
Major Frank North, Pawnee Scouts
Photograph of Bust of Old Jules Sandoz, Homesteader
Old Jules Sandoz, Homesteader
JOHN G. NEIHARDT CENTER
. Objects used along the road and at the old stage coach stations are on display in the museum.
Early ranches are also part of the story....
Drawing of a Colt Revolver
Colt Revolver
Drawing of A Cowboy's Tombstone
IN MEMORY OF James Willliamson KILLED BY INDIANS MAY 5 1879. AGED 28 YEARS A Cowboy's Tombstone
Homestead settlement of the area brought new people to western Nebraska. Museum exhibits depict their struggle to gain a foothold on their new land.
Still other displays illustrate the more peaceful aspects of life at Fort Robinson.
Period Setting in the Museum - Officer's Quarters, 1890
Period Setting in the Museum....... Officer's Quarters, 1890
Fort Robinson was an important focal point in the winning of the West and was an active military post from 1874 to 1947. Fort Robinson is now used as a Beef Cattle Research Station by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the University of Nebraska.
The Nebraska Park and Game Commission is developing recreational facilities at the Fort for the public.
The Nebraska State Historical Society invites you to visit its new branch....... THE FORT ROBINSON MUSEUM
